alt_statements.statement: As someone who spent a career in social work and still volunteers in my community, I believe policing has to be grounded in de-escalation, strong community relationships, and real accountability for bias and excessive force. We should invest heavily in training around mental health, implicit bias, and non-lethal tactics, and pair officers with social workers or crisis teams when possible. At the same time, we need clear, transparent standards for when force can be used and independent review when things go wrong, so the public can trust that safety doesn’t come at the expense of fairness or dignity.

As someone who cares deeply about safety for my family and respects law enforcement, I think we need to support police with better training in de-escalation, clear use-of-force standards, and body cameras to keep everyone accountable. I don’t believe in demonizing all officers, but I do think departments should be transparent about incidents, remove those who abuse their power, and work more closely with local communities so people feel protected, not targeted.

As a physical therapist who works with people rebuilding their lives after injuries, I see firsthand how trust and safety are foundational to any healthy community. We need policing strategies centered on de-escalation, rigorous bias and use-of-force training, meaningful accountability for misconduct, and deeper investment in mental health and community-based services, so officers aren’t asked to solve every social problem with a badge and a gun. At the same time, I support well-trained, fairly compensated officers who are integrated into the communities they serve, because effective, unbiased policing and public safety should reinforce each other, not compete.

Como alguien que valora el orden, la seguridad y la familia, creo que la policía es necesaria para mantener nuestras comunidades seguras, pero debe hacerlo con respeto y sin prejuicios. Se necesitan mejores entrenamientos en control de emociones, manejo de conflictos y trato justo a todas las personas, sin importar raza, idioma o estatus migratorio. También pienso que es importante que haya cámaras, supervisión y consecuencias claras cuando un oficial abusa de su autoridad, para que la comunidad pueda confiar en ellos. Si la policía trabaja con la comunidad, escucha a la gente y aplica la ley con firmeza pero con humanidad, se puede mantener la seguridad sin excesos de fuerza.

As a nurse who sees the consequences of violence and trauma up close, I believe policing strategies have to prioritize de-escalation, strong accountability, and thorough training on implicit bias and mental health crises. We need well-resourced alternatives for nonviolent situations—like mental health and social work teams—so officers can focus on genuine public safety threats. At the same time, I don’t want communities or officers left vulnerable, so reforms should aim to build mutual trust, clear standards for use of force, and consistent community engagement rather than simply “defunding” or demonizing police.

I think most officers are trying to do a tough job, but we can’t ignore that bias and excessive force have done real damage to public trust. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and mental health, stronger accountability when rules are broken, and more body camera use so everyone knows there’s a clear record. At the same time, we still need police to be able to respond quickly and firmly to serious crime, so reforms should focus on raising standards and transparency rather than tying their hands.

As someone who believes in both accountability and public safety, I think policing needs clear, enforceable standards on use of force, strong independent oversight, and mandatory body cameras to reduce bias and rebuild trust. We should invest heavily in de-escalation training, anti-bias education, mental health crisis teams, and community-based violence prevention so officers aren’t responding to every social problem with force. At the same time, departments must collect and publicly report detailed data on stops, searches, and force by race and geography so we can actually measure progress and hold leadership responsible for systemic change.

As someone who’s grown up in a diverse community, I think policing has to be centered on de-escalation, transparency, and real accountability so that no one is treated differently because of their race, background, or neighborhood. We should invest in better training on bias and mental health, require body cameras and clear consequences for misconduct, and shift some funding toward community programs and social services that prevent crime in the first place. That way, officers can still respond to serious threats, but public safety is built on trust and fairness, not fear.

As someone who supervises people every day, I know that clear standards, training, and accountability are what keep both workers and the public safe, and I believe policing should be no different. We need strong, enforceable rules around de-escalation, bias training that’s grounded in real community input (especially from communities of color and immigrants), and independent oversight when force is used. At the same time, investing in mental health services, housing, and youth programs will reduce the situations that turn into police encounters in the first place, making our neighborhoods safer for everyone, including officers.

As a mom and someone who wants my kids to grow up safe and respectful of authority, I think we need to back our police while also insisting on commonsense reforms. I support strong training in de-escalation, body cameras, and clear accountability for officers who abuse their power, but I don’t want policies that make cops afraid to do their jobs or keep criminals off the streets. We can reduce bias and excessive force through better hiring, training, and leadership without demonizing all law enforcement or sacrificing public safety.

I think police officers should try really hard to treat everyone fairly and kindly, no matter what they look like, because everyone’s life is important. They should get special training to calm people down without hurting them, and only use force when there’s truly no other choice to keep people safe. I feel safer when I imagine officers who are like good heroes, protecting people and listening to the community, instead of scaring them.

As someone who grew up under a regime in Cuba where the police were instruments of fear, I value strong but accountable law enforcement in this country. We should support our officers with better training in de-escalation and clear, consistent rules on use of force, while disciplining those who abuse their power based on bias. Body cameras, careful supervision, and community respect for the law can work together so that both the public and the police are protected. Public safety must never be sacrificed, but neither should fairness and equal treatment under the law.

I think police should be fair to everyone and not treat people differently because of how they look, and they should only use force when they really have to keep people safe. They should learn to listen carefully, be kind, and try to calm situations down first, like how my parents and teachers do when there’s a problem at school. I also think they should be honest when they make mistakes and work with our communities and churches so people can trust them and feel protected, not scared.

I think police should have to wear body cameras and get a lot of training on how to stay calm and fair so they don’t judge people just by how they look. They still need to stop dangerous crimes, but they should use force only as a last resort and explain what they’re doing so people can trust them more. Since I’m learning about different cultures, I feel like officers should also learn about communities they work in so they understand people better and don’t make unfair assumptions.

As someone who works nights and sees a lot from behind the wheel, I think policing has to be fair and consistent, with body cams and clear rules so officers are held accountable when they cross the line—but not micromanaged to the point they’re scared to do their jobs. We should focus on better training in de-escalation and dealing with different communities, plus more data transparency on stops and use of force, so we can spot and fix bias. At the same time, cops need the backing to go after real criminals hard, because my kids and I still depend on them to keep the streets safe.

As someone who’s spent a career in local government, I believe we need clear, consistent standards on use of force, strong accountability when officers cross the line, and regular, practical training to reduce bias and de-escalate tense situations. At the same time, I want my community to be safe, so I support giving good officers the tools, staffing, and community trust they need to respond quickly and effectively. Police and residents should be able to look each other in the eye at a neighborhood meeting or church event and feel they’re on the same side of the law, not on opposite teams.

As someone who spends a lot of time on college campuses and in diverse communities, I think policing has to be rooted in transparency, de-escalation training, and real accountability when officers misuse force. We can’t keep public safety on lock if whole neighborhoods feel targeted or afraid of the people who are supposed to protect them, so departments need stronger bias training, independent review boards, and more unarmed response options for mental health and non-violent calls.

As a Cambodian-American Catholic and a conservative, I believe we need both strong, well-supported police and firm safeguards against abuse. Officers should receive rigorous, ongoing training in de-escalation, cultural awareness, and bias, along with clear, enforced standards for use of force and transparent accountability when those standards are violated. At the same time, we must ensure they have the resources, staffing, and community trust necessary to keep our neighborhoods safe, because families like mine depend on stability and order. Body cameras, community outreach, and consistent consequences for misconduct can help rebuild trust without undermining the essential authority of law enforcement.

As a mom raising kids in a small community and trying to live simply and respectfully toward all living things, I think policing should focus more on de-escalation, mental health support, and knowing the people they serve instead of defaulting to force. We need clear accountability when officers abuse their power or show bias, but we also need them well-trained, fairly paid, and supported so they can do their jobs safely and fairly. Building real relationships between officers and neighborhoods—especially with kids and vulnerable folks—would go a long way toward reducing fear and tension on both sides.

As someone who’s seen a lot in my 92 years, I believe we need law and order, but we also need cops who treat everyone fairly and answer for their mistakes. Training should focus on de-escalation, knowing the community, and recognizing bias, but we shouldn’t handcuff good officers from doing their jobs and keeping folks safe. Strong oversight that’s local and transparent can help rebuild trust without tearing down the whole system.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in basic fairness, I think policing needs stricter standards, better training in de-escalation, and real accountability when officers abuse their power. We should support good cops with the tools and staffing they need to keep communities safe, while using body cameras, transparent investigations, and bias training to make sure everyone—no matter their background—is treated with respect.

I think police should try really hard to be fair and kind to everyone, because my teachers say everyone deserves to feel safe and respected no matter what they look like or where they’re from. They should have more training to calm people down without hurting them, and maybe talk to kids and families at schools and parks so we aren’t scared of them and they understand our neighborhoods better.

As someone who works in finance and has seen how bias can quietly skew decisions, I believe policing needs rigorous, transparent standards for use of force, paired with strong accountability mechanisms and independent oversight. We should invest heavily in de-escalation training, mental health crisis response teams, and community-based partnerships, especially in communities of color and Native communities that have historically faced over-policing. At the same time, officers deserve clear guidelines, good training, and support so they can protect public safety without resorting to unnecessary force.

As a school psychologist and local government employee, I see every day how trust, communication, and prevention matter more than reaction. Policing strategies should include strong de-escalation training, transparent accountability for use-of-force, and mandatory bias education, so officers better understand the communities they serve. At the same time, adequately funding mental health services, social workers, and school-based supports can reduce the situations that escalate into police involvement in the first place. We can maintain public safety while insisting on fair, respectful treatment for everyone—those goals are not in conflict, they depend on each other.

As a Black man who works campus security, I see firsthand how trust between officers and the community can make or break public safety. Policing needs stronger accountability, de-escalation training, and real consequences for excessive force, along with recruiting officers who reflect the communities they serve. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, education, and social support so police aren’t the only response to every problem. When people feel respected and heard, it’s easier to keep everyone safe without resorting to force.

As a nurse and a mom, I see every day how trust and respect literally keep people alive, and I think policing should be guided by those same principles. We need strong de-escalation training, real accountability for excessive force, and mandatory bias training so that people of color and immigrant families feel safe calling the police, not targeted by them. At the same time, officers deserve good training, mental health support, and enough staffing so they can do their jobs safely and thoughtfully instead of reacting out of fear or exhaustion. Public safety and fairness aren’t opposites—if communities trust the police, everyone is safer.

As a mom raising kids on my own, I want them to feel safe calling the police, but I also don’t want anyone—especially people of color or those in vulnerable situations—treated unfairly or harmed because of bias. We should invest heavily in de-escalation training, strict accountability for excessive force, body cameras, and independent oversight, while also expanding mental health responders and community-based programs so officers aren’t the default for every crisis. Real safety comes from trust and shared responsibility, not just from more aggressive policing.

As a Korean-born scientist, a widow, and a mother raising children in this country, I want policing that is both effective and deeply accountable, because my kids’ safety depends on trust between our communities and law enforcement. We need evidence-based training that reduces bias, strict transparency on use-of-force incidents, and independent oversight with real consequences when officers abuse their power. At the same time, we should invest in mental health services, social workers, and community-based violence prevention so that police are not the default responders to every crisis and can focus on serious threats. Public safety and civil rights are not opposing goals—they reinforce each other when policing is grounded in fairness, data, and respect for every person’s dignity.

As someone who wears the badge, raises kids in this community, and sees the world through both a sketchbook and a body cam, I think we have to be brutally honest about bias and use of force if we want real public safety. That means stronger de-escalation training, real accountability when officers cross the line, and policies that treat excessive force as a failure, not a gray area. At the same time, we need enough staffing, resources, and community trust so officers aren’t always operating in crisis mode and residents feel safe calling us for help. Public safety works best when we’re not an occupying force, but partners who know the neighborhoods, listen to people, and are willing to admit and fix our own mistakes.

My mom and dad always tell me that police should help everyone feel safe and be kind, no matter what they look like. I think grown-ups should make sure police learn to calm scary situations down without hurting people unless they really have to, and that they tell the truth when they do something wrong.

Como alguien que creció aquí y ve las noticias de casos de brutalidad, creo que la policía sí es necesaria para la seguridad pública, pero tiene que cambiar la forma en que trabaja, especialmente en vecindarios latinos. Deberían recibir entrenamiento fuerte y continuo contra el racismo y el uso excesivo de fuerza, usar más desescalación, cámaras corporales y transparencia, y trabajar en equipo con la comunidad, no contra ella. También quiero que haya consecuencias claras cuando un oficial abusa de su poder, porque sin rendición de cuentas no hay confianza. Si la gente confía en la policía, es más fácil prevenir el crimen y mantener a todos seguros.

As someone who spent a career caring for vulnerable children and now volunteers in my community, I believe our police officers need strong support, clear rules, and solid training to do their jobs safely and fairly. We should invest in better de-escalation and bias training, body cameras, and firm accountability for misuse of force, while also ensuring officers are not unfairly vilified and have the resources they need to protect law-abiding citizens. I want a society where people—especially the young and the elderly—can feel safe calling the police, and where good officers are empowered while bad behavior is swiftly and transparently addressed.

As someone who believes deeply in law and order but also cares about people’s well‑being, I think we need policing strategies that back good officers with strong training, clear standards, and real accountability when those standards are violated. Bias and excessive force should be confronted head‑on with better screening, body cameras, scenario‑based training, and community engagement, but without tying officers’ hands so much that they can’t protect the public. Data on stops, arrests, and use of force should be transparently tracked and reviewed, not to demonize police, but to correct patterns and improve performance. In my view, the goal is a professional, respected police force that enforces the law firmly and fairly, so that both officers and citizens can feel safer.

I think policing should focus more on de-escalation and community relationships, so officers actually know the people they’re protecting instead of just seeing them as threats. There needs to be better training to deal with bias and stronger consequences when officers misuse force, because everyone deserves to feel safe and treated fairly no matter their race or neighborhood. At the same time, I know we still need police to respond to real dangers, but they should be working with communities, not against them, to keep everyone safe.

As someone who spent years trying to teach teenagers about responsibility and fairness, I believe policing needs transparent accountability measures, strong de-escalation training, and independent oversight to address bias and use-of-force concerns. We can’t keep communities safe if large parts of those communities—especially people of color—don’t trust the police, so strategies like community-based policing, body cameras with clear public reporting, and bias training rooted in real-world scenarios are essential. At the same time, we should invest more in mental health services, social workers, and community programs so officers aren’t the default response to every crisis. That kind of holistic, eco-conscious approach to public safety aligns with my belief that institutions should do the least harm possible while protecting everyone’s dignity.

After a career in law enforcement, I believe we need strong, consistent training that emphasizes de-escalation, fair treatment, and accountability, while still giving officers the tools and support they need to protect the public. We should address bias honestly—through better screening, ongoing education, and firm consequences for misconduct—without demonizing the entire profession. Body cameras, clear use-of-force policies, and community engagement can build trust, but we must also stand behind officers who act within the law and in good faith to keep our communities safe.

Mi mami y papi dicen que la policía tiene que cuidar a todos por igual, sin ser malos con alguien solo por cómo se ve o de dónde viene. Yo quiero que los policías sean amables y hablen con las familias en el parque, en inglés y en español, para que no dé miedo cuando los vemos. Si tienen que usar fuerza, solo debería ser para que nadie se haga daño, y primero deberían tratar de hablar y calmar todo. Yo me siento más seguro cuando veo que la policía es justa y ayuda, no cuando grita o asusta a la gente.

As a 78-year-old Black man who’s seen both the best and worst of law enforcement, I believe we need honest reforms that address bias and excessive force without tearing down the good officers who keep our communities safe. Police should receive better training in de-escalation and dealing with mental health and disabilities, and bad actors should be held accountable, but we also need to support officers with proper resources and staffing so they can do their jobs well. I think building trust through community policing, body cameras, and consistent standards of conduct can improve safety for everyone. And as a Catholic and a conservative, I believe in law and order, but it must always be carried out with respect for the dignity and rights of every person.

As a conservative Catholic and former high school teacher, I believe we need policing that is firm but fair—officers must be held to high professional standards, including strong training on de-escalation, implicit bias, and dealing compassionately with people who have disabilities or mental health issues. We should invest in body cameras, clear accountability when force is abused, and community-based policing so officers know the neighborhoods they serve, while still ensuring they have the support, manpower, and legal protection to confront violent crime decisively.

As someone who cares deeply about both my kids’ safety and the well-being of our broader community, I think policing needs to prioritize de-escalation training, strict accountability for misconduct, and transparent data on stops and use of force, broken down by race and neighborhood. We should invest heavily in community-based alternatives—mental health responders, youth programs, and social services—so police aren’t the default answer to every problem, while still ensuring they have the training and support to handle truly dangerous situations.

As a young Black man with a disability, I’ve always felt that policing needs to focus more on de-escalation, mental health training, and strong accountability so that people like me aren’t automatically seen as a threat. I believe we can keep communities safe while also requiring body cameras, independent investigations of use-of-force incidents, and regular anti-bias training so officers truly serve and protect everyone, not just some.

As someone who believes in individual responsibility and limited government, I think policing should focus on clear, consistently enforced standards for use of force, backed by body cameras and transparent review processes so officers are held accountable when they cross the line. At the same time, we need to give good cops the training, support, and equipment they need to do their jobs safely, including de-escalation and bias training that’s practical, not just political theater. Public safety and civil liberties shouldn’t be in conflict—if policies are clear, data-driven, and applied fairly, we can protect both.

I think police should try really hard to be fair to everyone and not hurt people unless they really have to, because families like mine just want to feel safe walking and playing outside. They should learn about different cultures, talk nicely to people in the neighborhood, and use calm words before using force. I feel better when I see officers being kind and helping kids and parents, not just arresting people.

I think police should try really hard to treat everyone fairly and not judge people because of what they look like or where they come from, because in my church we learn that everyone is equal before God. They should get more training on calming people down without hurting them, but also still be there to protect us when something dangerous happens so kids and families can feel safe in their neighborhoods.

As a Black researcher who spends his days scrutinizing data and systems, I believe effective policing reform has to be evidence-based, transparent, and explicitly race-conscious. We need rigorous data collection on stops, searches, and use of force; de-escalation and implicit bias training tied to real accountability; and a shift in resources toward mental health, housing, and education so police aren’t the default response to every social problem. That approach both reduces the space for bias and unnecessary violence and strengthens the kind of community trust that actually makes everyone safer.

As a mom raising young kids and someone who works closely with people every day, I think good policing should be built on trust, transparency, and consistent standards that apply to everyone. We need better training in de-escalation and implicit bias, more use of body cameras and independent review of serious incidents, and stronger community involvement so officers really know the neighborhoods they serve. At the same time, I believe most officers are trying to do a hard job, and they deserve support and clear guidelines that help them protect the public without unnecessary force.

As a mom raising kids in a busy community and someone who believes deeply in fairness, I think our policing strategies need to center on de-escalation, bias training, and real accountability so everyone is treated with dignity, no matter their background. We can support officers in doing a tough job by giving them better training, mental health resources, and clear rules on use of force, while also investing in community programs, school support, and social services that prevent crime in the first place.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching young people and volunteering in my community, I believe policing must be rooted in respect, fairness, and accountability, with strong training to reduce bias and clear consequences when officers misuse force. At the same time, we do need well-supported, well-trained officers to respond quickly to real dangers, especially for seniors and vulnerable neighbors who depend on them. I’d like to see more community policing, mental health responders, and de-escalation tactics so that officers and residents know each other as people, not as threats. That, to me, is how we keep both our streets safe and our sense of justice intact.

As someone who works in holistic health, I believe policing should follow the same principle we use with patients: do no harm first, then address the problem with care and precision. We need robust de-escalation training, strict accountability for misconduct, and real community-based oversight to confront bias and excessive force, especially against marginalized groups. At the same time, officers should be supported with better mental health resources, training in trauma-informed approaches, and partnerships with social workers so that public safety is maintained in a way that honors the dignity and humanity of everyone involved.

I think police should be fair to everyone and get in trouble if they treat people badly just because of their race or how they look. They should have more training on how to calm people down without using force, and there should be cameras and rules so everyone can see what really happened. At the same time, we still need police to keep people safe from crimes, so the goal should be to make them more trustworthy, not to get rid of them.

As someone who cares about my neighbors and makes a modest living running my own little tailoring business, I want policing that treats everyone fairly and with respect, no matter their race, income, or neighborhood. I think we need strong, enforceable rules on use of force, more de-escalation and mental health training, and real accountability when officers abuse their power, paired with better pay and support for the officers who do the job right. At the same time, investing in community programs, housing, and mental health services can take pressure off police so they’re not asked to solve every social problem with a badge and a gun. That combination—firm accountability, community partnership, and social investment—is how we keep people safe and rebuild trust.

As a healthcare professional who works closely with people in pain and vulnerability, I believe policing must prioritize de-escalation, implicit-bias training, and strict accountability for excessive force, while still ensuring officers have the support and resources needed to respond effectively to real threats. We should invest heavily in community-based programs, mental health responders, and youth services alongside evidence-based reforms to use-of-force policies, so public safety is built on trust, fairness, and respect for human dignity rather than fear.

As a police officer and a father, I believe we have to confront bias and use-of-force concerns head-on without losing sight of our core mission: protecting the public and going home safe to our families. That means rigorous training in de-escalation, body cameras, clear and consistently enforced use-of-force policies, and leadership that backs officers who do the right thing while holding accountable those who don’t. We should use data and technology to identify patterns of bias, improve tactics, and increase transparency so communities see that we’re serious about fair treatment. Strong, fair policing and public trust go hand in hand; you can’t have lasting safety without both.

As a working mom and a moderate Democrat who believes deeply in equality and community, I think policing needs to focus on de-escalation, strong accountability, and meaningful relationships with the neighborhoods they serve. Officers should receive robust, ongoing training on implicit bias, mental health, and cultural competence, and departments should collect and publicly share data on stops and use of force. At the same time, I want my kids and our community to be safe, so reforms should support well-trained officers with the resources and staffing they need to respond quickly and fairly to serious crime.

My mom and dad tell me that police are supposed to keep us safe and help people, and I want everyone to feel safe, no matter what they look like. I think police should be kind and careful, use their words first, and only hurt people if they really have to so no one gets scared or feels treated unfairly.

I think police should try really hard to listen to people and not just assume someone is dangerous because of how they look or where they’re from. My parents always tell me that everyone deserves to be treated fairly and with respect, so officers should get better training to calm things down without hurting people unless they really have to. I still want them to keep us safe, especially kids, but they should be honest when they make mistakes and work with the community so people aren’t scared of them.

As a young Black girl who’s grown up seeing stories of people who look like me hurt or killed by police, I think we need stricter rules, better training on bias, and real consequences when officers use force unfairly. At the same time, I still want to feel safe in my neighborhood, so I’d like to see more community-based policing where officers actually know the people they serve, listen to us, and work on preventing problems instead of just reacting with violence.

Having lived nearly a century and seen both the harm and the good that authority can do, I believe policing must be rooted in accountability, de-escalation, and respect for every community, especially people of color who’ve too often borne the brunt of bias and excessive force. We need strong, independent review of use-of-force incidents, better training in mental health and cultural competence, and closer partnerships between police and the neighborhoods they serve so that officers are viewed as protectors, not threats. At the same time, maintaining public safety matters to all of us—especially older folks living alone like me—so reform should strengthen trust and effectiveness, not dismantle the basic function of keeping people safe.

As a Vietnamese American woman who values personal growth and social equality, I believe policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, cultural competency, and strong community relationships to reduce bias and unnecessary use of force. Officers should receive continuous training on implicit bias and mental health crises, and there must be real accountability and transparency when force is used, so communities—especially immigrants and people of color—can feel safe calling for help. At the same time, investing in social services, like mental health care and youth programs, will support public safety more effectively than relying on aggressive policing alone.

As a husband, dad, and warehouse worker who believes in both public safety and disability rights, I think policing needs more rigorous de-escalation training, strong accountability for excessive force, and real consequences when bias shows up in stops and arrests. We should invest in community-based approaches—like mental health crisis teams and youth programs—so cops aren’t the default for every problem and so people with disabilities and people of color are safer in encounters with law enforcement. At the same time, officers should have the support, training, and staffing they need to do their jobs well, because my family and coworkers still rely on them to respond quickly when there’s real danger.

As someone who values safety and order in my neighborhood, I believe we need strong, well-supported police, but they must be trained better to avoid bias and unnecessary force, especially against minorities and people with disabilities. I support body cameras, clear rules on use of force, and serious consequences when officers abuse their power, along with community policing so that officers actually know and respect the people they serve.

As an attorney and lifelong Californian, I see the rule of law as incompatible with systemic bias and unchecked use of force. We need clear, uniform use-of-force standards, mandatory de-escalation and anti-bias training, robust data collection on stops and incidents, and truly independent civilian oversight with real subpoena power. At the same time, we should invest in alternatives—such as mental health crisis teams and community-based violence interruption—so police are not the default responders to every social problem. Done right, these reforms don’t undermine public safety; they strengthen it by building trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

Mi mami y papi dicen que los policías deben cuidar a todos por igual y no pegarle fuerte a la gente solo por cómo se ve. Yo quiero que cuando crezca pueda confiar en los policías y que ellos sean amables y tranquilos, para que nadie tenga miedo y todos estemos seguros en el parque y en la calle.

As a young Black girl, I’ve grown up seeing stories of people who look like me being treated unfairly by police, so I think departments need strict rules, better training, and real accountability when officers use force. At the same time, I believe public safety is important, and that comes from building trust—having officers who know the community, don’t assume the worst about people, and work with neighbors, schools, and local leaders instead of just showing up when something goes wrong.

As a conservative, family-oriented mother, I believe we absolutely need strong, well-funded police to keep our neighborhoods safe, but that doesn’t mean we ignore real problems with bias and excessive force. We should focus on better training in de-escalation, mental health, and cultural awareness, along with body cameras and clear accountability when officers abuse their power. At the same time, we must respect good officers, support them with the resources they need, and encourage community policing so that trust can grow on both sides. This balanced approach protects our families and our rights without demonizing all law enforcement.

As someone who believes deeply in human dignity and quiet reflection, I think our policing strategies must start with rigorous bias training, strong accountability, and transparent reporting of use-of-force, so that every person is treated fairly no matter their race or background. We can maintain public safety through community-based approaches, better mental health support, and de-escalation training, which protect both officers and the public. As a liberal Catholic, I feel we’re called to value every life, and reforming policing in these ways is part of honoring that belief.

I think police should have to do a lot more training on how to treat everyone fairly, no matter their race or background, and learn better ways to calm situations down before using force. Body cameras and clear rules about when force is allowed are important so officers know they’ll be held accountable if they go too far. At the same time, I still want police around to keep neighborhoods safe, so I think building trust with the community—like officers actually getting to know people where they patrol—would help everyone feel safer and more respected.

My mom says police should be fair to everyone and not hurt people unless they really, really have to, and I think that’s important because everyone should feel safe, even when they look or act different. I think police should learn how to calm people down with words first and be kind, like the helpers at my church, so kids like me aren’t scared of them.

I back the police and know they’ve got a tough job, but I also think they should be held to high standards because they carry a badge and a gun. We ought to invest in better training on de-escalation and dealing with folks from different backgrounds, use body cams across the board, and have clear rules for when force is allowed. That way, the good cops are protected, the bad ones are held accountable, and law-abiding citizens can feel safer without tying officers’ hands when real danger shows up.

As a young person who cares about fairness and safety, I think policing needs clear rules, strong accountability, and better training to reduce bias and unnecessary use of force, especially against marginalized communities. At the same time, officers should be supported with resources for de-escalation, mental health response, and community-based programs so they can keep people safe without resorting to violence as a first option.

As someone who’s seen a lot of changes over 75 years, I believe we can have both safe communities and fair, accountable policing if we’re willing to be honest about bias and hold officers to high standards. Police should get strong de-escalation and bias training, wear body cameras, and face real consequences when they abuse their power, while also working closely with neighborhoods so people feel protected, not targeted. I’d like to see more funding for mental health and social services so officers aren’t the only ones responding to every crisis, and so force truly becomes a last resort.

As someone who works in corrections and takes public safety seriously, I believe law enforcement needs strong training and clear standards on use of force that are actually enforced, not just talked about. We should invest in better screening, ongoing scenario-based training, and body cameras to reduce bias and hold everyone accountable, while also backing officers who make tough calls in dangerous situations. Data on stops, arrests, and force should be transparent so the public can see we’re correcting problems instead of hiding them. Done right, this approach protects both the community and the officers who put themselves on the line.

As a mother raising kids on my own, I want the police to be respected and supported so they can keep our neighborhoods safe, but I also want to know they’re treating everyone fairly and with dignity. We need better training on de-escalation, clearer rules on when force is allowed, and real accountability when officers cross the line—without tying the hands of the ones who are doing their jobs right.

As someone who cares a lot about people’s wellbeing and fairness, I think police should have stricter rules and better training around de-escalation, implicit bias, and mental health so situations don’t turn violent so fast, especially in communities that already feel targeted. At the same time, we still need officers to respond quickly and effectively to real threats, but with more transparency, body cameras, and accountability when force is misused.

As someone who believes in law and order but also in the dignity of every person, I think police departments should focus on better training, including de-escalation and bias awareness, so officers are prepared to handle tense situations fairly. We need strong, well-supported officers on the streets, but we also need clear standards, body cameras, and accountability when abuses happen. Community policing, where officers really know the neighborhoods and the people in them, can build trust and reduce both bias and unnecessary use of force.

As a progressive policy analyst working in higher education, I think policing strategies need to prioritize de-escalation, rigorous bias training grounded in evidence, and strong, independent oversight to rebuild trust—especially in communities that have historically borne the brunt of excessive force. We can maintain public safety more effectively by shifting resources toward mental health responders, data-driven community policing, and clear accountability measures for misconduct, rather than relying on aggressive, punitive approaches that often escalate situations unnecessarily.

As a Black Nigerian woman and a Democrat, I believe policing must be rooted in accountability, transparency, and genuine respect for the communities they serve, especially communities of color that have carried the weight of biased enforcement for generations. We need stronger de-escalation training, real consequences for excessive force, and independent oversight, coupled with investments in mental health, housing, and community services so police aren’t the default response to every problem. Public safety should mean people feel safe calling the police, not afraid of them—and that only happens when officers are trained and empowered to protect life first, not just maintain control.

As someone who cares about both community safety and social justice, I think policing needs to be re-centered on de-escalation, rigorous bias training, and real accountability when officers abuse their power. We should invest heavily in community-based services—mental health responders, social workers, and youth programs—so police aren’t the first or only answer to every problem, especially in marginalized communities. At the same time, clear standards on use of force, body cameras, and independent investigations can help rebuild trust while still keeping people safe.

As someone who values law and order and has spent a lifetime teaching young people right from wrong, I believe we must support our police while also holding them to clear, consistent standards. We should invest in better training on de-escalation and fair treatment, ensure that misconduct is investigated quickly and transparently, and use body cameras so there’s accountability on all sides. At the same time, we shouldn’t handcuff officers from doing their jobs; they need the resources, staffing, and community respect necessary to protect innocent people and keep our neighborhoods safe.

As someone who cares a lot about practical results and feeling safe walking home from late shifts, I think we need policing that’s both firm and fair. Officers should get serious, ongoing training on de-escalation and bias, and there should be body cameras and clear accountability when force is misused, but we also need to support good cops with enough staffing, mental health resources, and clear rules so they can do their jobs without second-guessing every move. I’m not for “defunding,” but I do think some money should go to community programs and mental health services that reduce the situations where force is likely in the first place.

As someone who believes in equality and fairness, I think policing needs stricter accountability and better training focused on de-escalation and recognizing implicit bias, so people aren’t treated differently because of their race, disability, or background. Officers should wear body cameras, be transparent with their communities, and face real consequences when they abuse their power, but we also need them to have the support and resources to handle dangerous situations safely.

I think police should try really hard to be fair and nice to everybody, no matter what they look like, and only use force when there is no other way to keep people safe. They should talk and listen more first, like my teacher does when kids argue, and learn about different kinds of people so they don’t treat anyone unfairly.

I think police should try really hard to be fair to everyone and not hurt people unless they really, really have to. Grown‑ups should teach them to stay calm, listen, and talk things out first so people don’t get scared. I feel safer when I see officers being kind and helping people, not just chasing or arresting them.

As someone who values law and order and has seen over many decades how important the police are to keeping communities safe, I believe we should support our officers with better training in de-escalation and cultural awareness so they can avoid unnecessary violence and unfair treatment. At the same time, we must not tie their hands so much that they are afraid to do their jobs, because that only makes neighborhoods less safe. Sensible reforms, strong leadership, and clear standards can help root out real bias and misconduct while protecting the many good officers who serve honorably.

I think police should try really hard to be kind and fair to everyone, no matter what they look like, so people don’t feel scared just because of who they are. They should learn to stay calm and talk things out first instead of hurting people, and only use force if there is really no other way to keep everyone safe. If police spend time getting to know families and kids in the neighborhood, it would help us trust them more and feel safer playing outside.

As someone who cares deeply about justice and community trust, I believe policing needs stronger de-escalation training, strict use-of-force standards, and far more transparency—especially around data on stops, arrests, and force, broken down by race. We should invest heavily in community-based programs and mental health responders so officers aren’t the blunt tool for every problem, while still ensuring they have the support and training they need to handle genuinely dangerous situations.

As a conservative, family-oriented guy who believes in law and order, I think we absolutely need strong, well-supported police to keep our communities and kids safe, but we also need clear standards and accountability so that bias and excessive force are minimized. That means better training in de-escalation and cultural awareness, consistent enforcement of rules when officers step out of line, and support for good cops who do things the right way.

As a Brazilian-born, liberal Catholic and a special education teacher, I see every day how compassion, patience, and clear communication can transform conflict and misunderstanding—skills we should also demand from our police. Policing strategies must prioritize de-escalation, rigorous anti-bias training, accountability for misuse of force, and stronger partnerships with communities, especially with families and youth. We can’t talk about “public safety” if some communities—often people of color and immigrants—don’t feel safe around those sworn to protect them. True safety comes when officers are held to high standards, supported with proper training and oversight, and work collaboratively with schools, social services, and neighborhoods to prevent harm before it happens.

As a nurse, I’m held to strict standards of accountability and evidence-based practice, and I think policing should be no different: mandatory body cameras, transparent use-of-force reporting, and independent civilian oversight are essential to addressing bias and rebuilding trust. We need rigorous, ongoing training in de-escalation, mental health, and implicit bias, paired with clear consequences when officers violate policy. At the same time, investing in community-based services, like mental health crisis teams and violence interruption programs, can reduce the situations where armed police are the first or only response, improving safety for both the public and officers.

As someone who works in a safety-focused chemical plant and cares a lot about environmental and social justice, I think policing needs stricter accountability, better training in de-escalation, and real transparency to reduce bias and excessive force. At the same time, officers should have the support, resources, and community partnerships they need to respond quickly and effectively to serious crime, especially to keep families and kids safe.

I think police should treat everyone fairly and not judge people by how they look or where they’re from, because that makes whole communities feel scared instead of safe. They should get more training on how to calm situations down without using force right away, and also listen to kids and families in neighborhoods like mine so they understand what we’re worried about. If police showed they care about protecting us instead of just catching us doing something wrong, it would make it easier for people to trust them and work together to keep everyone safe.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime in a working-class job, around kids and families every day, I think policing has to be rooted in respect, accountability, and genuine partnership with the communities they serve. We need strong, mandatory de-escalation and anti-bias training, body cameras, and real consequences when force is abused—especially against marginalized groups—while also making sure officers have the support and resources to respond safely and effectively. Investing in mental health services, youth programs, and community-based interventions can prevent many situations from escalating to police encounters in the first place. To me, true public safety means protecting both people’s lives and their rights.

As someone who believes in community and fairness, I think policing needs strong accountability measures—like body cameras, better data on stops and arrests, and real consequences for misconduct—to address bias and excessive force. At the same time, officers should be trained in de-escalation, mental health crisis response, and cultural sensitivity, so they can keep people safe without resorting to force so quickly. I support shifting some funding toward social services and community programs, especially in vulnerable neighborhoods, because preventing crime through support and opportunity is just as important as responding to it.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how systems affect vulnerable environments and communities, I believe policing must be guided by rigorous, evidence-based reforms that minimize bias and excessive force while still protecting public safety. This means substantial de-escalation and anti-bias training, transparent data reporting, independent oversight, and reallocating some responsibilities—such as mental health or homelessness crises—to specialized civilian responders. We should treat community trust as a critical resource, much like a fragile ecosystem: once degraded, it is difficult to restore, and police policy must be designed with that long-term sustainability in mind.

As someone who backs the blue but also believes every life is precious in God’s eyes, I think we need both strong law enforcement and strong accountability. We should invest in better training on de-escalation, mental health, and community relations, while making sure officers who abuse their power face real consequences. At the same time, we must support good officers with the tools, staffing, and public respect they need to confront violent crime and keep our neighborhoods safe. Balancing firm, fair policing with transparency and body cameras can help reduce bias and excessive force without tying officers’ hands.

As someone who cares deeply about community, mental health, and justice, I think policing strategies need to center de-escalation, anti-bias training, and real accountability while shifting many calls—like mental health crises and homelessness—away from armed officers to specialized responders. We can still maintain public safety, but it should be done with strict limits on use of force, body-camera transparency, strong civilian oversight, and investment in social services that actually prevent harm instead of just reacting to it.

As a young Black woman, I’ve grown up seeing stories and videos of people who look like me being treated unfairly by police, so I think departments need serious bias training, real accountability, and body cams that are actually checked and enforced. At the same time, I want my neighborhood to be safe, so I believe officers should be better trained in de-escalation and in knowing our community, not just rolling through when something goes wrong. If police built real relationships with residents and faced real consequences for excessive force or discrimination, people would trust them more, and it’d be easier to work together to keep everyone safe.

As someone who spent a career looking carefully at facts and responsibility, I believe police need strong training, clear rules, and firm accountability to prevent bias and unnecessary force—but we must not undermine their ability to protect our communities. We should invest in better screening, ongoing education in de-escalation and cultural awareness, and transparent review of incidents, while still backing officers who act in good faith under difficult circumstances. Body cameras, community oversight boards with real but balanced authority, and consistent enforcement of standards can help rebuild trust. In my view, we don’t need to “defund” the police; we need to refine and support them so they can serve everyone fairly and safely.

As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe our policing strategies must prioritize the dignity of every person while still keeping our communities safe. We need strong accountability measures—like body cameras, transparent investigations, and independent oversight—alongside rigorous, ongoing training in de-escalation, bias awareness, and mental health response. At the same time, cities should invest more in social services, education, and community-based programs, so officers aren’t asked to solve every problem with the blunt tool of enforcement. That balance—firm standards, real oversight, and robust community support—is the best way to reduce bias and excessive force without sacrificing public safety.

As someone who cares deeply about social justice and works with kids every day, I think policing strategies must start with de-escalation, rigorous anti-bias training, and real accountability for misuse of force, especially in communities of color. We should invest more in mental health responders, community-based programs, and youth services so police aren’t the default answer to every problem. At the same time, clear, transparent standards for when force can be used—and body cameras with public reporting—can help maintain safety while rebuilding trust between officers and the communities they serve.
